page.title: 13HISTORICAL SITES BRAISHFIELD
page.content: At Broom Hill,on the N.border of the area,is an important archaeological excavation.A Mesolithic (Middle Stone Age) site where the remains of postholes & stakeholes of the oldest known dwelling in Great Britain & 3 other dwellings were found.The dating was done by the carbon 14 method. The excavations were started in 1970,& 89,272 implements & their waste products (struck flints) were found over 7 years. The camp site was used by hunters some 8500 years ago.For further information see"When the mammoth roamed Romsey"by M.O'Malley. ISBN 0906921 03 1 1982. JERMYNS LANE-The stream running under the road marks the site of death in battle of KYNGELAS (CYNEGILS) the first christian king of Wessex AD 643. Known locally as the Bloody Bridge.
